column16: Rooted in Goa’s relaxed spirit, "Susegad" celebrates life's simple joys through artful, hand-painted garments. Inspired by Khayati Suri’s passion for photography, music, and poetry, the collection captures scenes of cliff diving, gently swaying hammocks, and sunlit palm trees. Minimal yet thoughtfully detailed, each piece transforms everyday clothing into visual storytelling. Crafted in neutral hues for timeless appeal, "Susegad" reflects Asaii’s dedication to sustainable artistry, inviting wearers to embrace life's beauty, moment by moment.
column22: ["Organic Materials","Zero Waste Design","Non- Toxic Dyes","Natural Dyes","Sustainable Packaging"]
column28: Asaii blends art with sustainability, crafting hand-painted, eco-conscious apparel. With timeless neutrals and mindful, small-batch production, each garment tells an enduring story of thoughtful creation and conscious style.
column53: A celebration of Goa, India - time slows down, and the world fades away

column16: "Seeds of Change" transforms waste into thoughtful new beginnings, highlighting how small actions create lasting impact. Celebrating renewal and resilience, each garment is uniquely crafted from upcycled fabrics, enriched by distinctive hand-stitched details and subtle textures. Fluid yet structured silhouettes—oversized dresses, tailored coats, unisex jackets, and versatile co-ords—come alive in earthy, moody tones. Designed for versatility and longevity, the collection invites wearers to shape the future through conscious, one-of-a-kind style choices.
column18: Quilting, Patchwork, Embroidery, Hand Painting, Applique
column28: Doodlage redefines sustainability by transforming discarded textiles into stylish, upcycled garments. Rooted in circular design, the brand blends creativity with conscious fashion, proving that waste can be reimagined into timeless pieces.
column53: Inspired by the freedom of foraging

column16: "Petals from the Past" is an ode to nostalgia and renewal, weaving playful florals, polka dots, and stripes into relaxed, effortless silhouettes. A soothing palette of browns, purples, coral pinks, and blues offers cheerful yet refined charm. Crafted sustainably from upcycled modal, Tencel, bamboo viscose, and cotton slub, each versatile piece—tie-up tops, tiered dresses, pleated panels, and oversized fits—breathes new life into factory deadstock. Modern yet soulful, this collection proves sustainability can be beautifully wearable.
column28: Doodlage redefines sustainability by transforming discarded textiles into stylish, upcycled garments. Rooted in circular design, the brand blends creativity with conscious fashion, proving that waste can be reimagined into timeless pieces.
column53: An ode to nostalgia and renewal

column16: Doodlage is a trailblazer in sustainable fashion, breathing new life into discarded factory waste and post‐consumer textiles. Guided by a zero‐waste philosophy, the brand upcycles and customizes the raw materials into garments to keep fashion in circulation. Thoughtfully designed dresses, tops, and jackets feature patchwork, quilting, and deconstructed details, blending creativity with mindful consumption. Every Doodlage piece champions purposeful slow fashion that endures.
column18: Embroidery, Patchwork, Applique, Hand Dyeing, Quilting
column39: After gaining formal fashion education and experiencing the industry firsthand, Kriti was shocked by the sheer amount of waste in global fashion. Seeing perfectly good fabrics tossed out over minor defects made her question everything. That moment became her turning point - she knew she had to do something different. Kriti's first upcycling experiment, a collection she named Doodlage, laid the foundation for her brand. With Doodlage, she set out to prove that fashion doesn't have to cost the planet. Today, her work continues to reflect this belief - that fashion can be both beautiful and responsible, with every piece telling a story of transformation.
column42: Applique, Patchwork, Quilting, Embroidery, Zero Waste Design, Upcycling, Recycled Materials
column44: Doodlage rescues dead‐stock rolls, misprints, and cutting scraps, upcycling them into limited‐edition garments pieced with kantha‐inspired patchwork and quilting. Off‐cuts are shredded into yarn for fresh hand‐loom fabrics -driving near‐zero waste. Craft heritage powers every step: Bandhani tie‐dyes emerge from artisan families in Bhuj, while women‐led micro‐units around Delhi and Bengaluru handle appliqué and stitching under fair‐wage contracts. Natural turmeric and beetroot dyes mingle with organic cotton, banana, and bamboo fibres, creating fabrics that feel luxurious.

column16: The name "Asaii" symbolizes collective stories and interconnectedness, encouraging wearers to forge meaningful relationships with their clothing. Thoughtful, artistic, and ethically crafted, Asaii embodies the quiet elegance of conscious living. Known for meticulously hand-painted apparel, the label works closely with artisans using plant-based paints and responsibly sourced fabrics. Defined by a timeless, neutral palette, Asaii garments transcend trends, becoming cherished staples designed for longevity.
column39: Nimisha's journey to founding Asaii was inspired by the slow, peaceful beauty of Goa, where she lived for a time. The simplicity and sustainability of life there deeply resonated with her own values and became the foundation of her brand. After gaining industry experience, Nimisha launched Asaii, starting with shirts - a personal tribute to her dad. Known for her jolly, energetic personality, Nimisha's creative outlook is shaped by her mother, a talented artist who worked across various mediums. This artistic influence is at the heart of Asaii, infusing the brand with a unique, soulful vision.
column42: Hand Painting, Narrative Textiles, Organic Materials, Zero Waste Design, Natural Dyes
column43: Organic Materials, Zero Waste Design, Natural Dyes
column44: Asaii treats cloth like a blank page. In its studio, artists brush organic, plant‐based pigments across surplus cotton, linen, and bamboo, translating memories and custom stories into hand‐painted shirts, trousers, and shorts. Each stroke is singular-no two pieces leave alike. Circularity is woven in: leftover yardage becomes pockets, bucket hats, and totes, while coconut‐shell buttons and compostable mailers keep every detail earth‐kind. Even samples find redemption through #WorkDayCatharsis, a joyful paint‐splatter ritual that turns trial garments into limited art drops. Produced in small batches of roughly forty per size and finished under fair‐wage conditions, every Asaii piece is conscience, color, and craft in motion.
column53: "The Magic Always Lies In The Details-If You Slow Down Long Enough To Notice"

column16: Ituvana blends Indian and Indonesian influences into slow, soulful luxury. Think free-size silhouettes, expressive details like contrast stitching and appliqué, and natural fabrics crafted in small batches. Rooted in cultural storytelling and self-expression, each piece invites you to explore personal style beyond trends—fluid, thoughtful, and deeply individual.
column28: Ituvana—where ‘the forest of bliss’ meets conscious design—is a slow luxury label encouraging self-expression through free-flowing silhouettes, Indian-Indonesian roots, and timeless pieces crafted to evolve with the wearer.
column32: ananta_vana, maya_vana, pashm_vana, samadhi_vana, satori_vana, taman_vana, smara_vana
column39:
Ituvana was born out of Lylah’s passion for both film and fashion. Growing up surrounded by artists from various fields, she developed a deep appreciation for creativity and self-expression. Her journey led her to Donna Karan's brand, where she learned the art of silk draping, sourcing fine fabrics, and photography. But more than that, she discovered the power of connection and collaboration in creating meaningful change.
Before founding Ituvana, Lylah studied film and performing arts, which helped her find her unique voice and connect deeply with her emotions. Ituvana’s values are rooted in conscious living, preserving culture, and simplicity. She draws from the laid back lifestyle of Balinese and Indian cultures, and believes this intention infused in each garment impacts how the wearer feels.
column44: Ituvana cuts fashion loose from sizing rules. One-size dhoti pants that morph into a dress, hooded jackets with contrast kantha stitches, and hand-cut appliqué all share the same brief: feel good, last long, style many ways. Designers work with organic cotton and linen for day, fluid silk for night, and occasionally upcycle heirloom pashmina shawls into everyday wear—each small batch sewn in-house for tight quality control. Ancient kantha handwork runs quietly through the seams, while flashes of bandhani, tie-dye, and cutwork add modern edge. The result is a trans-seasonal wardrobe of re-wearable statement pieces, as inclusive and effortless as they are artful.

column16: AKHL is redefining fashion through structure and material. Inspired by tensile art and post-modern architecture, the brand creates sculptural silhouettes using experimental techniques. Known for its signature gradient palettes and light-responsive surfaces, AKHL brings a futuristic, art-driven edge to contemporary fashion.
column28: AKHL is a visual innovator creating structured silhouettes inspired by post-modern architecture and installation art. Known for their gradient palettes and light-responsive surfaces, they focus on material exploration and new fabrication techniques.
column39: Akhil’s journey into design began at Central Saint Martins, where he delved into technical textiles and material experimentation. He spent years mastering his craft, working with top Indian designers like Amit Aggrawal, and soon realized that high-fashion from India was often limited to familiar motifs and traditional fabrics. This sparked the creation of AKHL, where he combines unconventional yarns, innovative fabrics, and fresh structures to develop a unique design language that still honors traditional crafts. Akhil blends form, material, and technique to create modern, sharp garments that challenge the status quo, merging Indian craftsmanship with contemporary global aesthetics.
column42: Embroidery, Beadwork, Applique, Zero Waste Design, Artisans welfare
column44: AKHL Studio reimagines Indian handcraft through a bold, future-facing lens. Rooted in traditional techniques like ari embroidery, zardozi, adda hand-interlacing, and yarn hand-twisting, the brand pushes boundaries with experimental materials and forms inspired by global art and design movements. All pieces are crafted in-house by master artisans in New Delhi, who receive long-term employment, interest-free loans, and welfare support. Sustainability is central—AKHL follows a made-to-order model, minimizing waste and overproduction. By sourcing handmade, locally produced materials and rigorously testing for environmental safety, AKHL brings together innovation, responsibility, and craftsmanship in striking, slow-made fashion.

column28: Margn builds its world at the intersection of craft and function, blending traditional techniques with modern, performance fabrics. Inspired by the need for protection, it explores how clothing connects us across cultures and time.

column16: Margn builds its world at the intersection of craft and function. The label blends traditional techniques with modern, performance-driven fabrics—creating pieces that feel both rooted and forward-thinking. Inspired by the universal need for protection and shelter, Margn explores how clothing connects us across cultures, geographies, and time.
column28: Margn builds its world at the intersection of craft and function, blending traditional techniques with modern, performance fabrics. Inspired by the need for protection, it explores how clothing connects us across cultures and time.
column39: Saurabh and Ranjit came from farming backgrounds, and starting a fashion brand was never part of the plan. They graduated in 2019 and were working in different fields when the pandemic changed everything — Saurabh lost his job, and during that period they began exploring new ideas together. In 2021, curiosity and a shared desire to create something led to the birth of Margn. What started as a leap of chance grew into a brand that blends their creativity, passion, and fresh perspectives, crafting contemporary, thoughtful, and craft-driven fashion that reflects their journey and vision.
column42: Knitting & Crocheting, Quilting, Narrative Textiles, Organic Materials, Artisans welfare
column44: At Margn, craft is more than just technique—it’s about people, emotion, and community. The brand works closely with a women-led handknitting group in the Himalayas, where around 40% of each collection is made by hand. Innovation plays a big role, with designs like hand-knit puffers and trench coats blending tradition with everyday function. Margn also explores a new craft every season—not just in clothing, but in objects like woven mats or glass bangles. This curiosity keeps the process fresh and meaningful. For Margn, craft is a way to learn, grow, and build lasting connections across cultures.
